div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.p: Thursday, MARCH 14, 1907.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PROGRESS AND RADICAL CRITICS.
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., is contributing • series of articles to one of the newspapers in his constituency on the British control of Egypt. The first of this series of articles will be found in another column of to-day's issue After enunciating a number of truisms about che Government of this country interspersed with due tributes to Lord Cromer 8 work he binds up with the conclusion that, inasmuch as the material prosperity and financial solvency of the country have not been accompanied by moral and intellectual progress, therefore there is something rotten in the state of Egypt. This Radical critic of Anglo-Egyptian admi: nistrative methods falls into the common error of all his political kith and kin Their enthusiasms are generous but dangerous because they are based on erroneous generalisations Just as Mr. Massingham in his recent article in the "Nation" jumps to the conclusion hat the demands of the General Assembly are evidences of enlightened political intelligence, so Mr. Robertson holds that because Egypt prefers its old ethos, despite the fact that externally and financially all is changed, therefore there is something very wrong in Anglo-Egyptian methods. The truth is that we have been forced by circumstances to introduce western methods and ought not to expect immediate results. If we have been obliged to force the pace of external reform, it does not follow that the country ought necessary. arily to show a similar degree of progress, intellectual and ethical.

It might at once occur to some, who give a asty consideration to the subject, that our remarks are entirely belied by the rapid rise in hat is called civilisation of that, geographically, most Oriental people, the Japanese, at the comparison between them and the gyptians will not bear examination. The two ices are, in fact, totally dissimilar. The island position of the Japanese must be contrasted with the continental situation of Egypt, which has been the highway of every great invasión, it Persian, Greek, Roman, Arab, or French. here has, moreover, never been any national spirit in Egypt, for the very good reason that i'm the dawn of history they have never been warned by men of their own race. We all know the influence of climate, and that, too may have had its share in differentiating the Ftwo racoa. The true reason, the elemental factor of the everlasting unchangeableness of Egypt, may be probably sought in the circumg the distance that she possesses one single source o Jo.. life, to which every living thing must conform or vanish. The Nile is the only lord and give life to Egypt. The eternal type, in which the Great River has moulded the land and everything in it, must be implicitly.obeyed and all and every recalcitrant featuré must ets. either assimilate or succumb.

An instructive example of this was invention ed some time ago in one of the Balletins of the Khedivial Geographical Society, where it was remarked that some fine breed of Euro pean cattle, after being transplanted into Egypt for a few years, began to assume beladi characteristics. What is true of the stockyard is true also in history, Of al the many and mighty laces that have sojourned in the land not a single physical trace remains, and the influence of the centuries of Ptolemaic sovereignty are as much obliterated as the hundreds of years of Roman rule. There is a more modern case of this strange power of assimilation. For six hundred years during the Mamluk era there was a steady annual 'drafting of Circussian men and women into ERU Egypt ; yet there has never been a colony of pure Circassian race domiciled in Egypt. No · race can for long, withstand the racial and climatic influences of "a land where all things always seem the same." Lord Cromer in his Report on Egypt in 1903 drew attention to the fact that the conditions of life in ancient Egypt, as revealed by the Oxyrhynchus Papyri, point "to the conclusion that when, in recent years, Egyptian reform was taken seriously in hand, the reformers had, in many cases, to deal with practices which had existed, without undergoing any very material change, for at least 1,800 years." The game words probably were used 3,300 years ago by Rekhmara to Thothmes III. in an era of Egyptian prosperity as great as the present, when that statesman. of thirty-three centuries ago drew his sovereign's attention to the rapid progress Egypt has made of late years.

We are engaged in Egypt in an attempt to crowd the revolutions in fact and in idea, which in Europe have been the slow growth of centuries, into as many decades, without even halting to assure ourselves that things which owe their initiative to the genius of Europe, and are the ripening fruits of her maturity, are equally suited to the genius of the East. Even in the case of European civilisation; "while the advances made by objective science and its industrial applications are palpable and undeniable, it is a matter of doubt and dispute if our social and moral advance towards happiness and virtue has been great or any." So said a well-known English thinker; but to apply such reflections to modern Egypt might by some be considered to savour of heresy. That such a "point of view should be held here. tical is very natural, for it is a generally received fallacy of the present day that man, - as he exists, whether Oriental or European, is capable of net progress. We are always under an illusion of progress in Egypt, because wherever we are conscious of an evil we remedy it, and therefore always seem to ourselves to be progressing, forgetting that most of the evils we see are the effects, finally become acute, of long-unnoticed retrogressions, and that our compromising remedies seldom fully recover the lost ground. This is the illusion of illusions, whereby we judge that the follah, inasmuch as he is developing from a vegetarian to a carnivorous animal, sleeps in a bedstead, and uses the telegraph to gamble on the Alexandria Bourse in futures, is a more excellent person than his grandsire, who never ate nothing but "ful" and whose highest ideal of happiness was to escape the corvée. Why should we not think so ? Is oot the chauffeur, who drives a motor-car from Paris to Berlin, a more highly evolved man than the charioteer of Achilles ? Is not the modern Prime Minister a more enlightened ruler than Cæsar because he rides & tricycle and writes his despatches by electric light? Whilst man remains what he is, there can be no progress beyond the point already attained and fallen headlong from at every attempt at civilisation; and since even that point is but a pinnacle to which a few people cling in giddy terror above an abyss of squalor, mere progress should no longer charm us. The progress fallacy is widespread but very simple. We read of the old unregenerate Egypt and we conclude that the abuses of those days are quite things of the past. The curve is abolished, public education is made into a system, sanitary by-laws are multiplied, the Alexandria Municipality is founded, the octroi is done away with, irrigation is improved, the effendi wears tweed suits, the Bey drives motor-cars. All these and such-like changes produce an illusion of bustling progress, and it is inferred that the abuses of a generation ago no longer exist" except as interesting pages in Lady Duff Gordon's Letters from Egypt. But the moment we look for a reform due to the character of the people themselves we are disillusioned ; instead, we find that as they become more prosperous their criminality increases. This is no new conclusion. The lespair of institutions, and the inexorable "'ye must be born again," with Mrs. Poyser's stipulation, "and horn - different," recurs in every generation ; for man, as he is, never vill, nor can, add a cubit to his stature by any of the quackeries of progress Plus a change plus c'est la même chose, will ever be true of Egypt.

div.head: Khartoum Horse Show.
div.p: A horse show will be held at Khartoum tomorrow.

div.head: The Mahmal.
div.p: The Mahmal is expected to arrive at Tor on Saturday next.from Jeddah.

div.head: The Slave Trade.
div.p: The Repression of the Slave Trade Department liberated 3 Sudanese and one Charkes from slavery last month.

div.head: Executlon
div.p: Mohamed Khatiri Mohamed was executed at Hadra this morning for the double murder of two natives last October.

div.head: Plague Credit.
div.p: A credit of L E. 10,000 has been opened by the Government for the Public Health Department, for fighting the plague in Upper Egypt.

div.head: The "Dal."
div.p: The steamer Dal, which was said to have foundered in the neighborhood of the Sabluka, was able to steam back to the dockyard at Khartoum North, having sustained little damage.

div.head: Raid on Hashish Den.
div.p: A hashish den was raided last night mean the Midan Tewfik, Cairo. Twenty persons, mostly Berbereen, were found smoking hashish. The proprietor was arrested and the pipes, etc, seized as "pieces de conviction."

div.head: sentence for Assault.
div.p: Suleiman Khattab and Said Saria, who recently attacked and robbed two English ladies at Marg, have been sentenced by the Cairo Criminal Court to 6 and 4 years imprisonment with hard labour, respectively

div.head: Military Service.
div.p: A deputation of the Ababda Arabs header by Beshire Bey Gobran have been in Cairo and had an interview with the Sirdar. The asked him to exempt their tribe from military service. The Sirdar promised to accede to this request as a special case.

div.head: A Sudan Company.
div.p: M. Bonnel de Mezidres left Cairo last night for Khartoum in order to put the finishing touches to the important financial company which he is floating shortly. He had an audience with the Sirdar on Tuesday.

div.head: Body Found in the Nile.
div.p: On Tuesday afternoon, the deed body of native women, partly stripped of its flesh apparently by fish, was found floating upon the Nile in the vicinity of Kasr-el-Nil Bridge. The body, which appeared to have been in the water for some considerable time, was removed by the authorities to the Kasr El Aini Hospital where the usual examination and inquest will be held.

div.head: Motor Cabs for Calro.
div.p: It is said that a public service of some 20 motor cabs will be established in Cairo next season and that taximetres, or some suo equally satisfactory method of clearly denotin the fare payable will be adopted. Baron de Zuylen de Nyevel, president of the Automobile Club (to whom in particular is due the credit for the exi-ting excellent service of p bli motor fiacres in Paris), is actively interested in the undertaking, together with Messrs Ron Curphey, and an influential financial group.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: A musical correspondent writes : The excellence of the concert given at Lifonti's Hall of Friday evening deserves more than a passing comment. It was got up by Mr. MunGavin treasurer of the A.L M. and D.S. committee and was one of the best amateur performances we have heard in this city. It is sad to think that this society, which has weathered so many storms, should be just finishing up its fund by giving entertainment to the members It would appear that the organisation has fallen too heavily on the shoulders as a few of the committee and no one seemed inclined to take up the responsibility which had been relinquished by those wb had worked long and indefatigably, --som indeed for the la-t 17 or 18 years. procured a great deal of enjoyment, at a very cheap rate, for a number of people who cannot afford the prohibitive prices demanded for concerts and the Opera in this land of wealth The programme was full of interest, and ne stars made their first appearance as well as ol' friends, such as Mrs. Cree and Mr. Johnson Mr. Purvis, Mr. Fergusson, the Misses Fiten and Mr. Walter Sarjeant. The new prim donna, Mrs. Walter Sarjeant, was receive rapturously and each song was encored. He voice is of a delightful mezzo-soprano timbr and her singing is highly finished and show cultivation and refinement. Miss Horsfall, th pianiste of the occasion, is also new t Alexandria, as well as Mr. Hay, who plays his violin pieces with much taste and feeling It seems a pity when the musical element in strengthening and improving in quality as well as quantity that this society should be doomed to death in a few short weeks Could it not be revived under some other naine and under the protection of some stronger committee ? I met & want most distinctly and will certainly be mi sed not only by the British communit but by members of other nationalities.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Mobile sailed yesterday afte noon for Liverpool, via Malta, with pag-enger mails, and general cargo, including 4,832 bale cotton.

div.head:
THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
IBRAHIM PASHA NEGUIB.
div.p: We have received the following communication from Ibrahim Pasha Neguib in regard to ex the part he is alleged to have played in the or deliberations of the General Assembly:-
Le Caire, 13 Mars 907.
Monsieur le Directeur de "l'Egyptian Gazette".

J'ai été étonné de voir, dans une correspon-G dance du "Times," mon nom mela d uned ci-o sion prise par l'Assembl. e Générale. Je tiens • tl déclarer que jamais, aucun moment, je n'ai w eu, ni directement ni indirectement, aucun D rapport avec personne des membres de l'As-Ilio semblée Générale. Recevez, Monsieur le Di. recteur, ma considération la plus distinguée
IBRAHIM NAGUIB PACHA

The "Times" in its leading article on the General Assembly alludes to His Excellency's to | tactics in the following terms –The resolution requesting us to abdicate our rights and duties in Egypt in favour of an Egyptian Parliament was moved by Sheikh Aly Youssef, the editor of the Nationalist organ, "El Moayad," who, we are told, has • supplanted Mustapha Kamel in the good graces of the Court. He was assisted in putting pressure upon the members by Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, who actually holds office in the Government - as Under-Secretary of State for the Interior. It is significant of the state of mind of the members that the adopted these révolutionary proposals with little or no criticism. They voted them like sheep at the end of a sitting. | The wisest and most experienced Legi-latures in Europe would spend weeks on the consideration of projects involving consequences far less grave.
A Cairo native contemporary learns that a W number of natives intend to send a deputation to London next summer, with the object of placing the Egyptian nation's wants beforest the British people.

On last Thursday Mr. Dillon asked the de Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether his attention had been directed to the resolutions are passed by the Egyptian Assembly, and what at action the British Government proposed to y g adopt in view of them
Sir E. Grey : I have seen some of the reasons the solutions referred to, but no action on the part of the Government appears to be called for.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive returns" to Cairo this evening

div.head: KHEDIVE'S A.DIC. ATTACKED.
div.p: We hear that Thuriyssen Pasha, while shooting near Gizeh with two or three servants, was attacked by a number of fellaheen. The Pasha escaped with some bruises, but one of o his servants is said to have been badly hurt.

div.head: EXPLOSIVES IN THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: The full question asked in the House of eCommons last Thursday, with reference to fo at the resolutions of the Egyptian Assembly, and P the conveyance of explosives through the Suez Canal, a summary of which was cabled 1, by our London Correspondent, was as follows:--

Dr. Rutherford asked Sir Edward Grey whether, seeing that,apart from the £34,000,000 of the share capital of the Suez Canal Company owned by his Majesty's Government, there were three British directors representing his Majesty's Government and seven British directors representing British shipping inter. rests on the board, as well as in view of the probable . adhesion of the Government of the French Republic, in which i the bulk of the company's share capital waste | owned, his Majesty's Government would en-se deavour to introduce regulations for the purpose of minimising the danger to the canal, to shipping, 'and to the lives of passengers from carrying explosives through the canal. Sir E Grey : I have nothing to add to the reply which I made on Nov. 22 last. It is obvious that it is to the interest of the company to take proper precautions, and that they are in the best position to judge what precautions are necessary.

div.head: THE DISTURBANCES AT BEIRUT.
div.p: The Secretary of the Imperial Ottoman + Embassy in London writer to the "Daily Telegraph" with reference to a report recently appearing in that journal to the effect "that the situation at Beirut was rapidly growing or worse, that the foreign consuls protested against murder, anarchy, and fanaticism, but without effect, and that the population, Musa sulmans and Christians alike, was arming, but e that the Vali was afraid to take energetic measures.``
The Ottoman Embassy is authorised, says as. the Secretary, to declare that all these reports are absolutely groundless.

div.head: SALT AND SODA CO
div.p: The strike of the Salt and Soda Company's It employés is at an end owing to the conci liatory attitude of the management, which has undertaken to examine their claims in & reference to the transfer of the company's headquarters to Alexandria.

div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano

Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day with Monthly Terms
Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber.

div.head:
ROYAL VISIT TO EGYPT.
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S ARRIVAL.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are expected to arrive in Egypt on the 3rd April, ol on their way home from India. The Royal visitors will be the guests of Lord Cromer at the British Agency, and will only remain three days in Egypt. Two days will be spent in Cairo, where the Duke, who is InspectorGeneral of the Forces, will hold an inspection of the Garrison. On the third day (Friday, the 5th) the Duke and Duchess of Connaught i will come down to Alexandria, where the Duke will pres new colours to the 2nd Batta- lion Royal Dublin Fusiliers at Mustapha. | Their Royal Highnesses have signified their intention of honouring the annual amatenr athletic sports with their presence, and the date of the meeting has therefore been altered to the 5th April to suit their convenience. The Duchess has kindly consented to distribute 1 the prizes.

div.head:
SANIEH GIRLS' SCHOOL,
ANNUAL DRILL DISPLAY.
div.p: In spite of other attractions, many ladies e found their way to the Sanieh Girls' School on Wednesday afternoon, when the annual drill display and sale of work was in progress. From the road outside no one could have any idea of the brightness and charm of the big.airy build ing which, with its wide verandahs and corridors, is built around the square garden within. It was a gala day for the big crowd of happy looking children who in dainty white frocks with sashes and hair-knots of various colours thronged the verandahs all ready for the afternoon's performances. Miss Johnstone and her staff stood ready to receive guests, and soon after Lady Cromer's arrival the serious business of the afternoon commenced. The students of the Training College were the first to March across the paved path across the garden sand give a short display of dumbbell exercises. t They were promptly followed by a bevy of the o younger scholars, their Boy white frocks relieved with sashes, etc., of belivtr pe, and they performed their Swedial exercises with a tpre-ision and briskness that spöke volumes for the training that had been bestowed upon them. They in their turn were followed by a delightful crowd of kindergarten babies who trotted placidly to their place and spoke their little recitations with delightful naiveté ; "The three little kittens" being recited with much expression and evident enjoyment. The children of the preparatory class armed with scarlet scarves and sashes did their scarf drill, and others with touches of pink about them performed pretty evolutions with small hoops covered also in pink. Then there were other recitations and pole exercises hy a class whose dresses were relieved by touches of green in various shades, and finally a maypole dance was performed by eight tiny tots with great aplomb and much holding out of little skirts and pointing of baby toes. The entire display, with its happy-looking bands of juvenile perco formers, was in every way a most credible d performance and compared very well with ve those other displays of a like nature in England. It was delightful, too, to watch the same -- children in the great big playground after y wards, fitting about in their pretty frocks and osashes, busily employed in games, swinging, etc., and as thoroughly enjoying life as any t, English children on an extra half-holiday. 8 In another building the sale of work was h in progress, the elder girls taking charge of the - various stalls. There were some beautiful v examples of needle.craft on exhibition, drawn linen work, needle lace, and embroidery, which h it would be hard to/beat So much were all us these pretty articles in request that by the - end of the afternoon there was scarcely en article which did not bear the magio ticket 1, "Sold" upon it.
Tea was served upon the verandah, the children acting as excellent hosts and attendants ; their politeness and pretty manners being fitting complements to their bright faces and dainty frocks.

Most of the classrooms and dormitories were thrown open for inspection ; and school life under such ideal conditions would be shorn of half its horrors The best of school. room fitments are in requisition : the latest | patterned desks and all the usual paraphernalia n to which we are accustomed to at home. The elder students who are being trained especially | for teachers have their own separate classrooms and the work they do therein redounds much to their credit. Some 25% of the pupils (there are over 200 on the rolls) are boarders, and their dormitories are bright, airy apart ments furnished with the same attention to detail as all the rest of the school.

Miss Johnson may well be proud of her - school and her big flock of pupils : for accus| tomed as we are to such entertainments among girls' schools at home, we have never witnessed anything better arranged or more satisfactory than this annual display at the Sanieh School. We hope at some future date to be able to give a further and more detailed account of this school and of the excellent training it is giving to such numbers of the coming generation of Cairo.

div.head:
THE VILLAGE TRAGEDY.
NATIONALIST TACTICS.
div.p: We learn that M. Grandmoulin, who is accused of wilful murder and what not by the *Egyptian Standard," was carrying his gun in one hand just before the accident at Warrak and with the other holding his bicycle. He was just about to take his gun to pieces when e he heard a boy who was with him cry out and turned sharply to see what was the matter. The gun exploded and the charge struck another boy who had come up unnoticed by M. Grandmoulin and killed him. The story that M. Grandmoulin had an altercation with the boy is absolutely false : he had not seen him before the gun went off.

Such is the lamentable event out of which "Al Lewa"and its European gladiators are attempting to make capital. M. Grandmoulin is an eminent jurist of 60 years of age, the last man ia the world to shoot a child in cold blood, but probabilities are nothing to the "Lewa," and the fact that M. Grandmoulin was director of the School of Law at the time of the students' strike has doubtless contributed to the bitterLess with which he has been attacked. But the real motive of the attack we realise too fally: incitation against the European-despite the grandiloquent device anent freedom a d Hospitality which . decorates the "Egyptian Standard." It is part of the game played before the Alexandria riots, played during the Akaba incident, played during the past summer. Some-day these incitations will lead to bloodshed, and the miserable dupes of Mustapha Pasha and his followers perforce atcne for the deliberate and studied incitations of their leaders.
The French Consulate at Cairo is holding an enquiry into the matter.
We understand that M. Grandmoulin contemplates bringing an action against "L'Etendard Egyptien."

div.head: HOTEL FOR PORT SAID
div.p: A group of capitalists are contemplating the erection of a palatial hotel-casino on the front at Port Said. The hotel building will cost £20,000. The plans have been sent to the Governor of the Suez Canal, who will submit them to the Government.

div.head: LUXOR GIRLS' SCHOOL
div.p: On Wednesday week the Luxor Girls' | Boarding School, under the superintendence cf Miss Buchanan, gave its annual entertainment connected with the presentation of diplomas to the graduating class of the school. Many guests of distinction were present, both native and foreign. Among the foreign were Miss Helen Gould, of New York, Prof. Sayce, of Oxford (who-addressed the audience in a taost charming and well chosen speech), Miss | Hazard, LI.D., President of Wellesley University, America (who delivered the diplomas), | Miss Bruce, of Edinburgh, Mrs. F. Cook, and others well known both in England and America. After the exercises, which consisted of high Arabic essays by the advanced classes and songs and drills by the intermediate classes, the large audience of over six hundred went | up to the second floor of the fine new building to see the display of beautiful needlework done by the Egyptian girls.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF A LEVIATHAN.
div.p: The White Star Line steamer Arabic, as |duly announced, arrived in port yesterday morning early bringing a large number of Amee rican tourists who were speedily landed and Tsent off by special train to Cairo. Some of them will remain in the capital for a few days and some will continue their journey to Luxor and Issouan. The lunding of these passengers was el conducted in a manner reflecting a great deal of praise on the management of the F. C. Clark Company as everything seemed to work very smoothly. The monotony of the journey from e ship to shore had been carefully considered, - and in order to relieve that, monotony the F. Jo. Clark Company had thoughtfully provided la native band and a few Sudanese dancers.

To people coming to Egypt for the first time this feature will have no doubt 1 appealed very forcibly, but to the old stager it will appeal with redoubled force, especially - Considering that this thoughtful provision will not only have saved time in rendering a visit to the native bazaar a work of supererogation e but will at the same time have saved money 'The F. C. Clark Company is to be congratulated on having got ahead of the other tourist agencies in this respect. The music and dancing were very much appreciated, judging by the amount of backsheesh received by the per- formers.

div.head: M. PHOTIOU'S RECITAL.
div.p: M. Photiou's recital at the Khedivial Hotel I yesterday was well attended and proved very pleasant M. Photiou is the possessor of a good, powerful voice, less remarkable for timbre than for balance. In reducing it to the compass of a small concert-room, he shewed a fine feeling of restraint without detriment to verve or expression We could have wished for e rather less hackneyed selection, for it consisted chiefly of those arias from modern ItaTian opera which are to be found "in every home." M. Photiou's rendering of them was tiniformally successful. Owing to the regrettable indisposition of Herr Brockhnisen, some changes had to be made in the programme und we had an opportunity of appreciating Mlle Philippaki's well-executed mandolin solos, with Mlle Seritidės at the piano. Sig. Mirės also gave us a dexterous Tarantella of his own composition.

div.head:
BRITISH CONTROL OF EGYPT.
THE CONSULAR AUTOCRACY.
div.p: Mr. JM Robertson writes as follows in the "North Mail" of Newcastle. We have dealt with the article in our leader :

"Never, I think, has such a political situation occurred in British history as that which now exists in Egypt ; indeed, it would be difficult to match it in any European history whatever. In many records we meet with governors of.. colonies and dependencies who are allowed a pretty free hand, whether by constitutional or unconstitutional governments. But a governor who is allowed more power than a nominally! absolute ruler ; a governor whom his "home" 11 Government never dreams of "instructing":, a governor so privileged that no one ever seeks to overrule him, his only difficulties being those inseparable from his task-such a potentate is hard to find in history before Lord Cromer.

In naming that distinguished man, I desire to say that any ensuing criticism of mine is directed first and last against the system of: which he is the 'no adethat all against the man as man. Some people assume that all that is needed to secure the proper government of Egypt is to recall the present Consul General and heads of departments, and appoint others in their place. And, indeed, this simple theory of things is countenanced by Lord Cromer himself, who is fond of quoting Talleyrand to the effect that the secret of good government | consists in finding the right men for the different posts. On that view, serious miscarriage means merely that there should be a change of men.
THE SYSTEM, NOT THE MAN.

I take leave to challenge such a view, in Lord Cronier's own interest. Under his 11 supremacy, some branches of Egyptian administration have gone far wrong ; but, looking at the administration as a whole, one is bound to admit that in other regards we might go further and fare worse. As regards finance in particular, no one disputes the wisdom of Lord Cromer's management. Another man might easily set up a much better educational policy, for instance, and a much worse financial.

The question, then, is not one of men but one of systems ; not one of administrative, errors, but of rigl t or wrong conditious of administration. And the general case against the present system is that it is in its essentials a negation of every regulative principle on which the government of the British Empire has been, and is, carried on in any other quarter of the world. India and the Crown Colonies are, in comparison, constitutionally governed. Colonial governors can initiate nothing save under approval of the Colonial Office. The Viceroy of India consults with his Council, and the whole machine is subject to the control of the Secretary of State in London, who is advised by his Council.

Over Egypt there is hardly a semblance of control ; of reality there is none. In reply to a question in the last Parliament it was officially avowed that the Ministers of the Khedive must do what the British ConsulGeneral insists upon. That is to say, the British Army of Occupation in Egypt will, if necessary, enforce his orders. The ConsulGeneral, on his part, has declared in one of his reports that, far from being a "benevolent despot," he is under the orders of the Foreign Secretary, who is responsible to the British Parliament. That is the theory of the situation, so far as any theory can be said to exist. But the actual fact is that the Foreign Secretary takes no cognisance of anything done in the Egyptian Administration save when it is forced on his notice ; that he seeks to exercise no control ; and that be deprecates, directly or indirectly, any request that he should overrule the policy of the Consul-General at Cairo.

In saying this I am not criticising personally Sir Edward Grey any more than Lord Cromer. The present Foreign Secretary did not create the anomaly of the present British control in Egypt, any more than did his predecessor. Entering into the heritage of that anomaly, he seeks to get along with as little friction as possible. To impose an effective home control on the Consul-General at Cairo would involve something like the establishment of a new Government Department in London.- Sir Edward may legitimately argue that for the Foreign Office to undertake to supervise the entire government of Egypt would merely be to set up an anomaly.
ABSOLUTISM.

But the mere official wish for official peace and quietness cannot fitly be allowed to deter.. mine the policy of democracy in this country as regards Egypt The present system is one which could never have been contemplated, save as a momentary arrangement, by any British Government. Neither Liberals not Tories could ever have planned that for an indefinite term of years, possibly for generations, a series of British Consuls-General should exercise a practical autocracy in Egypt. No amount of esteem for any one Consul-General could reconcile rational statesmen to the thought of making the office of Consul-General in any country one of practically irresponsible power. The situation is admittedly one which has grown up fortuitously, as the outcome of a series of reluctant and opportunist interventions ; and it is more than time that so irregular and so indefensible an, arrangement should be thoroughly reconsidered

That it has been allowed to exist so far is: unquestionably due to the general British opinion that Lord Cromer has managed Egyptian affairs very well, inasmuch as he has put the finances on a sound footing, met all the charges of the national debt, and so dealt with irrigation that the material prosperity of the count- try has visibly advanced. On the financial pore, foreign States have acquiesced because the claims of their subjects holding Egyptian bonds have been steadily satisfied.

The first requisite, however, for a jnat judgment of the Egyptian situation is a full reógnition of the fact that mere material prosperity and financial solvency would not be regarded in any European country of high civilization as an ideal state of things, if accompanied by moral and intellectual protest ; nay, would, in the latter case, be regarded almost as a dangerous symptom. and that the moral and intellectual results of the past quarter of a century of British domination in Egypt have been seriously unsatisfactory, I propose to show in subsequent articles. That they should be unsatisfactory night, I think, be seen by thoughtful politicians o be inevitable. But I propose to show as much, in detail, to those who decline to take I for granted.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANY NOTICES.
div.p: Application has been made to the Committee of the London Stock Exchange to appoint a special settling day in United Egyptian Lands, Limited-Ordinary Shares of £1 each, 5s, paid, and 'Bearer Warrants for Ordinary Shares of £1 each fully paid, Nos. 1 to 343,757 and 143,758 to 498,750, and to allow the following mecurity. to be quoted in the official list : Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited, Further issue of 40,000 Four-and-a-Half per Dent. Debenture Stock.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Cromer went to Al Azhar University yesterday and returned the visit which Sheikh Hassouna El Nawawi had paid him at the British Agency a few days ago.
The Sirdar leaves Cairo for Dongola on the > 27th inst
Saad Pasha Zaghloul has returned to Cairo" From his tour of inspection in Dakahlieh.
Sir Malcolm McIlwraith, C.M.G., returns to Cairo on Saturday next.

We learn by telegram with deep regret that the father-in-law of Count Bernstorff, German Diplomatic Agent, died in Paris yesterday at the age of 71 years; after having undergone * serious operation last week. The return to Cairo of Count Bernstorff and his family is therefore yet uncertain.
The Egyptian officers, at Khartoum gave an "at home" at their Clab last Thursday to meet H.E. El-Lewa Henry Pasha, Adjutant General

The "Progrès" announces that Mr Verschoyle, Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower: Egypt, slipped and fell while playing football the other day. This mishap has way said to have prevented him from attending to his official duties, which will be temporarily undertaken by Mr. Williams. There is no truth in this account of Mr. Verschoyle misadventure at football, as he is not a votary of that pastime. Mr Verschoyle caught a chill a few days ago and pneumonia has, we regret' to hear, supervened.

Among the passengers who embarked yesterday on the Schleswig were the following:-Sir Alfred and Lady Cooper, Comtesse de Fénélon, Baronne de Kubeck, Comte and Comtesse de Mérode, Comtesse Anne Louise Mérode, Lady MacLeod, Baron and Baronne Ribeaupierre, Comte and Comtesse Michel de Zogheb, Mrs. Scotter, Mr. and Mrs. C.L. Painter, etc.
Lieutenant M. G. Dill, MB., Royal Army Medical Corps, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Ariny, with the rank of Bimbashi, and is posted to the Medical Corps.
The passengers by the train de luxe for Upper Egypt on Tuesday were :-Mr Everet, Mr. Maus, Mr. Eaken, Mr. Skinner, Miss Johnstone, Mr. S.K. Knoes, Dr. Heskitt, Mr. Braun, Mr. Johnstone
Mr. H P. Kingham has subscribed £2 to the funds of the Deaconesses' Hospital in memory of the late Mr. Henry Barker.

div.head: ATHLETIC SPORTS.
div.p: Athletic sports in connection with the Moslem Benevolent School at Beni Souef will take place to-morrow, near the Government School, under the presidency of the Moudir of Beni Souef. We are asked by the headmaster of the school to state that he will be pleased to see any tourists or European residents who may wish to attend the sports. Admission will be free and refreshments will be supplied. gratis. The sports commence at 2 p.m. Beni Souef is two hours from Cairo by rail.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.
LADIES' TAILORS.
(high class work only).
CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

House of Commons.-A recriminatory debate took place . yesterday evening on the Colonial Vote. The Opposition. taunted the Government with sanctioning in the New Hebrides worse conditions than those of the Chinese labour in the Transvaal. They charged them with gerrymandering the Transvaal in the interest of the Boers, who have now proved themselves in no wise hostile towards Chinese labour..
Mr. Winston Churchill and Sir E. Grey warmly responded, upholding the New Hebri. dos Convention and rebutting the accusation · of favouring the Boers.
Sir E. Grey strongly deprecated making the Chinese labour question the cause of friction between the Transvaal and Imperial Governments.
(Reuter)
369 of the Iena's complement, out of 698, answered the roll call yesterday night. 60 are known to be in hospital. The fate of the remainder is uncertain.
The Ministry of Marine ascribes the explosion to a short circuit.

The Iena was lying in the dry-dock at the time of the explosion. The captain of the battleship Patrie, which was lying near, pre. vented the spread of the conflagration by firing a shell, which smashed the dock-gates, letting in the water with which the lena was flooded.
King Edward and the Emperor William have sent messages of condolence. (Reuter)
The Iena appears to be a total loss. The number of those missing is 114. Telegrams of condolence are reaching the Elysée from all countries. (llavas)
General Botha's speech has greatly appeased the Progressives and contributed largely to diminish the bitterness of the electoral conflict.
(Reuter)

The death sentences 'passed on Petieff and Potgieter for their participation in Ferreira's raid have been commuted to 15 years' impri. sonment, and in the case of the other raiders to imprisonment for life.
(Reuter)
Two gold ingots, valued at £1,600, were "stolen at the South African Exhibition last night. Up to the present no arrests have been made. (Reuter)
The family of B1. Perier have declined a state funeral, at the deceased's special request.
(Reuter)
It is stated that M. Petkoff's assassination was the result of a political conspiracy. (R)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: THE SULTAN AS KHALIFA.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, - The widely divergent views expressed by several correspondents in the "Gazette' reflect truly the conflicting opinions held ir Islam on the position of the Sultan as Khalifa | Indeed, ever since the death of the prophet - Mohamed, nol question has arisen in the Moslem world which has caused so much trouble and division amongst the faithful as that of the Imamate or Khalifate.

"Verily there is no prophet (to come) after me, and the time is near when there will be after me a great many Khalifas," said Mohamed but he took no steps towards appointing any person to the post, and this, undoubtedly, foi the reason that he wished the office to be an elective one, and to give his followers full liberty of choice. For a time the will of the people prevailed, but later on the post became the prey of the strong man and it has remained so to this day in so far as it has existed as an office, though it is true the Sultan of Turkey on ascending the throne is formally elected Khalifa by the College of Ulema at Constantinople.

The necessity for such a head was not that of religion or law, but of administration. The law, both spiritual and temporal, as given in the Koran, was final and still remains above the office of Sultan or Imám : but an administration requires & head, and as long as the world of Islam formed one state, one leader - sufficed. When, however, in the course of time Islam was divided into independent states, each state required its own Sovereign, and here came the parting of the ways in Islam between spiritual and political interests, and out of thi: arises the difficulty of dealing with Moslem affairs from the inside as well as from the outside.

The idealist in the Pan-Islamic movement seeks to bring about greater unity among Moslems on spiritual lines only; the Egyptian Nationalist declares that he has no wish to submit himself and his country to Turkish maladministration ; both agree in looking for light and leading to Constantinople. But to differentiate between spiritual and temporal interests is to militate against the primitive conception and fundargental characteristics of Islam. To set up a spiritual authority pure and simple is without precedent and has the whole weight and force of history against it. An exception to this might be cited in the case of the so-called second dynasty of the Abbassides (not generally accepted by Moslems as true Khalifas) who, from 1258 to 1517 of the common era, enjoyed only a nominal religious authority under the Mamelukes in Egypt. It is often the boast of the Moslem that "Islam has no priesthood"; it can therefore have no high-priest. On the other hand it is quite certain that the average Muslem cannot conceive of a Khalifa except as an absolute leader in all things, nor does he value the importance of any subject, especially in his dealings with the "infidel," except in so far as it relates to the faith

Now according to the Ashariya, or orthodox school, every candidate for the office of Imam must be of the tribe of the Quraish and be duly elected by the consent of the people. In neither of these points is the Sultan of Turkey qualified, and so the quotation given by your correspondent, Mr. Cheetham, "the Sultan cannot be regarded as the true Khalifa;" taken (literally, is correct. But there is another principle well recognised in Islam, which is, that when the Imamate has been usurped by a per-on not possessing all the necessary quali fications, if his rule be just and in accordance with the teachings of the Koran and the traditions, it is better to acquiesce and submit. Moreover, the Sultan, holding as he does the positions of ruler of the only Moslem state of first class importance and of protector of the holy places, and having in his hands the appointment of the Sherif of Mecca (the most Bacred post in Islam), can claim to be de facto the only possible Khalifa and defender of the faith.

Such then to-day is the chaotic state of I thought and belief in the Moslem world on the question of the Khalifate. Whether the idealists can ever succeed in spiritualising the deep sense of brotherhood in Islam : whether the masses can ever rise above that feeling of the necessity of a titular head (the same sense which created the Pope and made him infallible), and whether such a leader, once possessed of the full confidence of the followers of the, faith would rest content with spiritual authority only,are deep questions and form tuo big a subject to be discussed in a letter of this Vind. They are however full of interest and of no little importance.--Yours, etc.

div.head: The Money Market,
div.p: The money market remains in very much the same condition, with a bright outlook, but with no lower rates or prospect of a change 1 in the Bank rate for some time. Things in America are in the seething pot for the present, and everybody is acting, in money as in stocks; on the safe side. This is as it should be, and will no doubt be productive of greater ease in the spring, which is the most important time of the year, when some considerTable flotations are likely to take place.

The demands of the London County Council will be very considerable, but with the more', conservative administration it is probable & there will be no difficulty in arranging for their requirements on satisfactory terms. 1 Surprise is still expressed that larger amounts of gold do not come from Egypt, and there is much speculation as to the quantity you will be able to retain of the eight to nine millions i you have received from this side. |

The Bank return is again somewhat colouriess. The stock of gold and bullion is lower by £641,000, notwithstanding that only £99,000|1 on balance went abroad, this shrinkage being 1 due to the usual outflow of currency incidental to the turn of the month. The note circulation | has expanded, by £244,000, and the total reserve is' £885,000 lower at £26,408,000, 1: which compares with £26,054,000 last year. The ratio of reserve to liabilities has fallen 25 to 447 per cent., which is 2 percent below the ratio twelve months ago.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: The frenzied finance which has been characteristic of Wall Street during the past week has not merely demoralised the stock markets there, but has also been the dominating adverse | factor on the Stock Exchange here. The disorganisation which the scare has caused in 1 Throgmorton St. gives a somewhat misleading idea of the extent to which London dealers are committed in American stocks and shares. As a matter of fact the American speculatives position here was very considerably reduced d. ring the shake-out recently, but in the pre-11 sent nervous state of most markets, the | wild operations in New York have naturally 11 had the effect of emphasising the weakest spoty. The final result of this will, of course, be salutary as regards future operations, but brokers are finding it difficult to view the present situation from this philosophical standpoint.

The chief feature of interest for the moments is the Japanese new conversion Five per cent. luan, which is to be issued to-night at 994 This would appear to be absurdly cheap iu view of the present price of the Four-and-a-la Half per cents. which, even in the face of it still stand at 939. Of course the price of the latter are being artificially. sustained during th the period of issue of the new loan They lo will no doubt fall to the proportionate level as soon as the latest issue is all taken up. Til The quotation for the new loan is only 1 percent premium, which would make the 45 percent. worth only about 90, |

The overwhelming defeat of the Progressives at the County Council elections has 16 been received with great satisfaction on the Stock Exchange. The extravagant policy of that party had caused grave uneasiness in financial circles for a long time past, and it is confidently anticipated that the saner policy to which the new majority have committed themselves will do much to revive many enterprises which have suffered much from oppressive legislation and continually increasing taxation
Markets have continued depressed to-day, and.quotations are again generally lower.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: The gilt-edged market has displayed considerable weakness, and notwithstanding renewed purchases by the Government broker, have continued to follow a downward course. Yesterday they fell to the lowest point of the year. They leave off to day at 86 to, d. for the account, a further fall to day of 1/8.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The Japanese new loan is attracting much attention in the foreign market. The new issue is for twenty three millions, which will be chiefly devoted to the conversion of the present six per cents. It is expected that holders of the six per cent. Customs Bonds will be offered in exchange for their existing scrip a £100 new Five per cent. bond, fully paid, and entitled to 15 a half year's dividend in October, besides a one per cent. cash bonus. A large portion of the issue will be placed in Paris |
In view of the new loan, the old issues have been offered, the Fours being very flat. All the stocks show declines of 1/8 to 1/4 to-day.
Russians were firm at the beginning of the 3 week, but have since eased off, the Fives shedding 1/4 and the Fours 1/8 yesterday. The Fives have further declined 1/8 to 85 1/2 to-day.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: The home railway market started buoyantly enough, the result of the County Council contest being regarded as a very favourable point, but for the greater part of the week, the tone has teen anything but satisfactory. The changes are in nearly every case adverse The Caledonian and North British dividends have been received with much disappointment. The Caledonian declaration is at the rate of 31 per cent on the Ordinary stock, as against 4per cent. last year, while the carry-forward at £20,500 is practically unchanged. The Deferred stock receives per cent. for the year. The North British result is even worse. This is at the rate of per ognt, with $10,500 forward.

The Caledonian announcement was followed by a fall of a full point in the Deferred stook and in the Preference, while other Soottish, stocks were affected, North British Deferred dropping , and Glasgow and South Western Deferred t. The following day there was some recovery, but the North British declaration yesterday gave the market another cold douche, and British Deferred slumped 7/8 to 32 7/8, and the Preferred were marked down a fall point. Caledonian Preference gave way 1/2. Yesterday Brighton "A" were the only bright spot, these registering a gain of 1/2 .
There has been continued liquidation in this market to-day. Brighton "A" have relapsed 1, Great Western 1, North Western and South Eastern "A" 3/4, and Caledonian Preferred 1/2.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The enormous realisations in New York, which amounted in one day alone to 2,357,000 shares, have caused prices here to fluctuate violently, and in several cases very low levels have been touched. Indeed, the declines in values have been so serious, that there is much misgiving as to the ultimate result of the settlement next week. The sharp advance in Readings which followed the large purchases of the shares by the Harriman clique, who were reported to be desirous of securing control of the line, gave some strength to the market for a time, but this has been followed by further extensive liquidation. Americans have again been heavily sold to day. Lo isville have shed 4, Aitchison 3, Chesapeake 33,Reading 24, Unions -25, and Southern Preference 2.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: The Egyptian market has been quiet, and in several cases shares have been offered, but there are few buyers about. This of course applies to the speculative group only. National Bank of Egypt fell from 287 to 27 sellers, and Agricultural Bank from 9) (ex-dividend of 9/ per share) to 88, but the latter are now firmer at 9 to. The 81 % Debentures keep steady at 90-1. Daira Sanieh Ordinary have been very flat, and have been offered down from 165 ex dividend to 15 . before finding a buyer. The Deferred are nominally 90, but it is difficult to get a bid. Egyptian Estates are dull at 2 , while Delta Land & Investment are nominally 31-4. New Egyptian are quoted 1-5, but there are only sellers at 24/g. United Egyptian Lands are to premium, and the Deferred about 9. Khedivial Mail are supposed to be 17d, and Union Foncière are 54-68 without any market. Land Bank of Egypt leave off at 85-95, and Bank of Abyssinia 14 dis. count. Delta Preference (Bearer) at 11+ are fairly steady, considering the fall in other shares. Egyptian Markets at 1g and Salt & Suda'at 1-3 are unmentioned.

div.head: 'Mining.
div.p: Business in the mining market has been on a very reduced scale. A few specialities have received attention, and for the most part the tone has been steady, but the shares generally have been affected by the depression ruling in other sections of the House Dealers are dig. posed to reduce their commitments in view of the differences which have to be met at the forthcoming settlement.

Yesterday Kaffirs, after being dull during the day, took a sharp turn for the better in the Street, and Rand Mines recovered from 67 to Gid, while East Rands and Goldfields were in demand at 4 de and 4. : The tone in Kaffirs to-day has been rather more favourable. Raud Mines and Gold Fields are each to better.
Egyptian mining shares have again had a very quiet week, and the changes are confined to a fall of 3d. in the Nile Valley to 4/8.
Egyptian Mines Exploration are steady at 3, 8., and Egyptian at 1 1/16

div.head: RHEUMATISM'S CAUSE.
div.p: A Disorder of the Blood. This Lady was quite a Cripple. Pain in every joint.
Cured by the Rich New Blood Plentifully Made by
DR. WILLIAMS PINK PILLS

The fault of the Blood -- that is the direct cause of Rheumatism in every form; and as the disease proceeds from the blood the only way to a cure is by renewing the blood supply That is why Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People are so eminently successful in Rheumatism and other blood disorders, because they actually make strong red blood that cleanses the system of positions and builds up health k anew with full relief from pain. 1. " All my joints were inflamed with Rheu tematism four years ago," said Mrs. Burdin, ol 7 50, Archdeacon-lane, Leicester, when interview ned recently, "and from a strong active woman I dwindled away to a pitiable wreck THESE WERE unable to do anything in the HER SYMPTOMS. house. What I suffered will be partly understood when I tell you that agonising pains flew through my back and limb | as though my muscles were gripped by pincers, while an icy feeling crept down my spine. My flesh and bones became sore, and I felt as though I had been beaten all over. "Every change in the weather set up fresh attacks and increased my pain. Sometimes I could hardly drag one foot after the other, and " in time I became quite a cripple. Then rheumatic fever developed, and I had to take to my bed, where for fourteen weeks I lay in Jagony, Every movement of my body caused excruciating pains to shoot through me ; my body twitched with agony, for it seemed as though I was being stabbed with red-hot needles. |"My fingers became knotted and my skin puffed ; also, my flesh was so tender that I I could not bear the weight of the bed clothes, and I had to have supports to save them from touching me. My breathing became short and sharp, and my heart palpitated. I grew as weak and helpless as a child, and terribly emaciated, with my nerves in such a bad state that I could not stand the daylight, and the room was kept darkened. "In spite of all the clever treatment of doctors I seemed to get worse ; the medicine they gave me produced nausea, without relieving my agony. " But at this time my husband was strongly advised to give me Dr. Williams Pink Pills for Pale People, and though-I fully believed I was beyond cure, I consented to try the pills. After a steady course of the pills I was pleased to notice a decided improvement: I continued, and the pains began surely to diminish ; before long I could move my hands. *This encouraged me so much that I persevered with Dr. Williams' Pink Pills; then my strength returned until I was able to sit up in bed ; I began to put on flesh; I gradually regained the use of my limbs, and was able to venture out of bed. ** From the time I began Dr. Williams' Pink Pills I never looked back; they alone restored me from a hopeless cripple to the strong, healthy woman you now see. This Propsectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies
The Subscription list will be open for one day only, vis, the 16th day of March 1907, at the Company's Bankers, The Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmic
Cairo and Alexandria.
THE AUTO-GARAGE AND AUTO-CABS Company Limited.
(Incorporated under the Companies'. Aots, 1862 to 1900.)
DIVIDED INTO
5625 Ordinary Shares of £4 each = £22,500
AND
5000 Founder Shares of 11- each = £ 250/$22,750

According to the Company's Memorandum of Association, the profits of the Company of each financial year which shall remain after setting aside a sum equal to 7 per cent. of the value of the Company's plant or such larger amount as the Company may think necessary foi providing for the renewal and augmentation of the Company's plant are applicable as follows:
First. To the payment of a cumulative preferential dividend at the rate of 6 per cent per annum on the Capital for the time being paid up on the ordinary shares to the close of such year.
Secondly. Five per cent thereof is to be carried to the Company's general reserve fund
Thirdly. Of the residue of such balance 10 per cent. is to be divided between the Directors as additional remuneration for their services.

Fourthly. Of the surplus of such residue 50 per cent. is applicable to the payment of & further dividend on the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the. Capital paid up thereon and 50 per cent is applicable to the payment of dividend on the Founders Shares in proportion to the capital paid up thereon
In a winding up of the Company the Assets distributable amongst the members are ta be applied.
First, In paying off the capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares and all arrears of the cumulative dividend thereon whether declared or not to the commencement of the winding up

Secondly. Or the balance 50 per cent is to be distributed amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the Ordinary Shares held by them respectively and the other 50 per cent is to be distributed amongst the holders of the Founders Shares in proportion to the Founders Shares held by them respectively.

1875 Ordinary Shares are now offered for subscription at par: payable 10/- per share on application y allotment and the balance in three instalments of £1.- each at intervals of not less than two months from each other.

Any subscriber for ordinary shares aforesaid who receives an allotment will have a right to subscribe at par for one Founders share in respect of every 10 of the said Ordinary Share allotted to such subscriber. Share Warı ants to Bearer will be issued after full payment of the shares. Founders shares shall be fully paid in Allotment

PROSPECTUS.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular to manufacture, deal in, sell and let on hire motor cars and motor cabs and also to acquire and take over from the Vendor a9 & going concern the garage business carried on at Cairo by Mr. Christos Loukaitis. ..
The Company will have a spacious garage and workshops well furnished with tools for the repair, manufacture and alteration of motor cars

The Vendor Mr. Loukaitis has been appointed General Manager of the Company for a period of five years from the incorporation of the Company at a salary of £600 per annum and he is bound not to engage in any business in Egypt of a nature calculated to compete with that of the Company.

The property included in the sale comprises the. Vendor's business, hig garage at Cairo held on lease for an unexpired term of five years (dating from 20th March 1906) at the moderate annual rental of £180 and the full benefit of all pending contracts and engagements and subject to all pending trade contracts and engagements.

The purchase price has been fixed at £2500 or such legs sum as shall be certified by two valuers one to be appointed by the Vendor and the other by the Company or their umpire to be the true value of the property to be sold.
The whole of the purchase price viz: £2000 will be satisfied by the allotment to the Vendors or his nominees of 625 fully paid up ordinary shares of £4 each in the Capital of the Company.

The balance of 5000 Ordinary Shares after deduction of the 625 which are to be issued as fully paid to the Vendor, has been underwritten by the Directors including the Vendor in the following proportions: H. H. Prince Aziz Pacha Hassan 4/60 tbs., Mr. T. N. Koressios 10/60ths., Mr. E. Manusardi 7/50ths., MrJS Gali 7/50ths., Mr. E. Buccianti 47/60ths., UrN. Chakour Bey 5'50ths. and Mr. C Loukaitis 10 50ths.

Of the 5000 Founders shares, 500 are reserved for allotment to subgèribers for ordinary shares in the proportion of one Founders share for every ten ordinary shares and the remainder 29,000 Founders shares are to be divided between the Founders of the Company and the Vendor, according to the Agreement dated 13th June 1906 and this as remuneration for the underwriting of the above 5000 Ordinary Shares
The minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 10 percent of the shares offered.

The Contract for the sale of the business is dated the 1st August 1906, and made between the said Christus Loukaitis of the last part, all the above named Directors and the said Christos Loukaitis of the 2nd vart and Nechib Ayoub of Cairo As Trustee for the Company (then about to be registered) of the 3rd part

The above mentioned tuo contracts have been adopted by a further contract dated the 7th February 1907 and made between Theodor Nicolas Coresgy-Koression and Emile Manusard of Cairo both Directors of and on behalf of the Company of the 1st part and Christos Loukalt of Cairo being the vendor of the 2d part and Neghib Ayoub, Advocate of Cairo as trustee foi the Company of the 3rd part.

The Articles of Association provide that the qualification of every Director is to be the holding of shares or Stock of the Company of the nominal value of £ 200 and that a first Director may act before acquiring his qualification.

The Articles of Association also provide that the Directors shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for their services the percentage of profits specified in the Company's Memorandum of Association and such further sums as shall from time to time be determined by the Company in General Meeting and that such percentage of profits and further sums (if any) shall be divided among them in bunch proportions and manner' as the Directors by agreement may determine and in default of such determination equally. They also provide that the remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be Axed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits or by any or all of these methods and they also provide that if any Director being willing shall be called upon to perform extra services or to take any special exertions in going or residing abroad or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate such Director either by a fixed pum or by a percentage of profits or otherwise as naay be determined by the Directors and such remuneration may be dither in addition to or in substitution to his share in the remuneration as herein before stated.
The preliminary expenses up to allotment for the incorporation of the Company are estimated at £600, the stamp duty is included in this amount and payable by the Company. for
Copies of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and of the above mentioned Contracts can be inspected at the Company's Office in Cairo at any time during business hours. is
A Copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is printed on the back of this prospectus and forms part of it.

Application for shares should be made upon the form accompanying the prospectus and sent to the Company Bankers, the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio Cairo and Alexandria, together with a remittance for the amount of the deposit. Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments Failure to pay any future instalment on shares allotted when due will render previous payments liable to forfeiture
Prospectus and Forms of Application can be obtained at the Company's Office in Cairo and Alexandria.
Dated Ciiro the 23rd day of February 1907.

Kerr and Wyatt an Caire, rpe Kasr el Nil, lumeable Chawarbi Packs, pour de bérer sur l'ordre du jour suivant:
1. Lecture du rapport du Conseil d'Admi. nistration sur le troisième exercice social.
2. Leotard du rapport des rongeurs et fixation de leur indemnité.
3. Approbation des comptes du troisième exercice.
4. Nomination d'un administrateur en remplacement de M. J. W. William son, administrator sortant et rééligible.
5. Nomination d'un Congé pour l'exercice 1907.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

La débâcle 'est générale. Nous fléchisseur sous une avalanche d'ordres de vente, prov. nant surtout du Caire, tandis que la hausse du taux d'escompte, accompagnée d'une nouvell baisse du la rente et du consolidé maintien à l'écart les capitalistes. Les baissiers en profitent pour vendre à découvert et il faut avouer. que les circonstances leur font beau jeu.

Parmi les banques, l'Agricole Fléchit à 9, National Bank à 27 1/4, la Cassa di Sconto 229 1/2 l'ancienne, * 226 la nouvelle et 216 1 la toute nouvelle, la Land Bank . 9 3/4, Comptoir 6 7/8 l'ancienne et 6 9 16 la nouvelle, le Banco di Roma á 112, et le Crédit Franco-Égyptien 5 15/16.
La Behra perdu livre 39, la Delta Lam 5/16 • 8 9 16, les Estates 5/32 à 2 1/16, Building Lands 3/16 à 5 7/16, etc.
La fondation Et Nous s'effondre à 3 7/8 l'action * 27/82.
De 1 1/8 l'Investment tombe offert A 1 1/3: prix qui ne s'était jamais vu depuis la fonda tion de la société.

Telles sont le fluctuations les plus intéressantes. Si l'on ajoute que les prix inscrits sur la côte sont généralement surfaits, on aura une idée de la situation. D'un optimisme exag on est tombé sans transition au plus complet découragement. Ce qui le prouve c'est la r duction du prix des reports. On ne reporte plu on liquide. Tant mieux. De cette façon il y espoir d'une reprise.

div.head: Ciroulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Mercredi 13 Mars 1907.

La taux de l'escompte libre à Londres en monté hier de 1/88 5 pour cent, ce qui le port au niveau de l'escompte officiel de la Barca d'Angleterre. Ce renchérissement du loyer d l'argent sur le marché libre semble indiquer qu'on s'attend à une augmentation du taux d la Bagnole, déterminée à protéger sa ré-erv contra les besoins pressante de New-York Adesi bien, en Stock Exchange, le Consolid anglais a encore baissé de non moins de 8/8 85 S.S. L'Unifa a également perdu 1/4 à 10 La National Bank s'est misintenne à 27 8/4 L'Agricole a gagné 1/8 à 9 1/4. L. Daïra es domoda inchangée à 15 7/8. La Delta Light a rétrogradé de 1/8 à 11 1/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien est resté avarié à 745, de même que la Banga. d'Athènes à 137.

Impressionné par le resserrement monétair à Londres, ainsi que par la mauvaise tenue du Stock Exchange, déprimé par la baisse constante des Railways américains et canadiens notre marché des valera est resté, ce matin dans son attitude passive et expectante; avez tendance générale à la lourdeur par suite, do nombre très restreint des transactions.

Dans le compartiment des Banque, la Na tional et l'Agricole, délaissées, ont Abobi 27 5/8 et 9. Ls 1988 di Sconto a faibli à 231 l'action ancienne 228 la nouvelle, et la dernière Admission à 219. Le Comptoir Financier s'est alourdi à 7 1/16 et sa part à 8. La Baigor d'Orient s'est tassée à 182-183. ·
Le Crédit Foncier & rétrogradé . 740 et le Daïra à 15 7/8. L'Enterprise and Development est remontée à 11 1/2. L'Allotement est revend à 3 1/16.
Bo bonne tenne, les Entrées prises Immobilière et Travaux ont progressé à 8 1/16; fear part à old taré à 122. L'Epargne Immobilière est restée à 2 13/16 et sa part à 135,
L'Express Nile a avanos à 5 1/4-5/16 l'action ancienne ; la nouvelle s'est maintenue à 4 5/8 et la part à 145.
Les Jouissances Ex dd Caire ont perdu & francs à 270. Les Ciments ont décliné à 45.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovich, très soutenu", sont remontés à 28 11/16. Les Egyptian ont reculé à 11 7/8 et les Upper Egypt á 4 3/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, lea Delta Land ont faibli & 3 7/8, les Estates à 2 3/16 et leur part à . Les Markets ont rétrogradé 24 sh. 6. les New Gyptian & 24 sb. et les Walker and Mei Marachi à 0 9/16. Il y a en, comme hier, an bon mouvement sur les parts de fondateur Egyptian Land Investment and Building, qui ont olótaré à £ 4 1/2.
Dans sa dernière revue financière "The Egyptian Gazette" dit au 'sujet de la situation du marché égyptien :

"S'il y avait jusqu'ici beaucoup de positions aarobargées qui se rapportaient péniblement depuis plusieurs moi", la plupart d'entre elles ont da, à l'occasion de la baisse othello, se liquidør og toast au moins s'alléger. Les aob tears pour fio ont eu le même sort. Et si, à l'heure qu'il est, le malaise persiste, il est do sans doute à l'abstention des gros capitalistes. Mais tout, maintenant, milite en faveur d'une reprise : le niveau atteint pour nombre d'excellents titres, niveau inférieur à celui de la saison d'été, les profits énormes retirés de la vente da coton et les bénéfices provenant de la plusvalue de sol ; autant de capitaux qui vont chercher un emploi et qai, certainement, a'iront pas s'engouffrer dans de nouvelles émissions qui n'ont pas encore fait leurs preuves, tandis qu'il se trouve tant de bonnes valeurs rémuné. rations dojk OF D068. En un mot, les raisons de la baisse sont purement transitoire, et accidentelles, tandis que celles de la baungo sont permanentes,"

On annonce de Londres la formation d'une nouvelle Société anonyme pour l'Egypte 800g la dénomination de "Cairo Sand Bricks Co," ad capital de £100,000, représenté par 98,750 notions ordinaires de £1 et 25,000 parts de fondateur & 1 bolling.
L'objet de la Société est d'acquérir le fond et de continuer les affaires de l'Abbatial Sand Brick Co.
Le promoteur de la nouvelle Société e: M.P.M. Singer, directeur de la succursale d la Banque de Salonique au Caire..
L'émission de "Thu Auto-Garage and Auta Cabs Co." est fixée à après demain 15 Mar courant.
Cette Société 4 poor président S.4. le princ Az z paoha Hassan.
Nous avons déjà appon é que l'assemblé générale ordinaire de l'Union Foncière d'Égypte bers tenue le 27 Mars courant au siège social Alexandrie.
On rapporte que le dividende proposé serai de P.E. 37 1/2 par action.

div.head: Cloture de la Bourse Khediviale
div.p: CONTRATS
Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchand. 6h. p.m.
REMARQUES
COTON-Nouvelle recolte: Demandee, mais addaires restreintes, faute de vendeurs. Cours tres fermes.

Recolte nxxmelle: Eu commerve a achere dans l'aores-midi et cela a contribue a raffermir les cours. En cloture nous acons au une legere reaction, mais quand meme nous resions en benefice de 7/82 sur la coture de 1 heure.
Dans la matinee prix plus haus pour mars talarie 12 3.32 a -/-; plus bas pour mars 12 1/16 a -/-. Dans l'apres-midi prix plus haus pour mars 12 3 8 a -/-; plus has pour mars 12 7/32 a -/-.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
